title: 108_hr3514
content: The Pennsylvania National Forest Improvement Act of 2004 includes provisions for the disposal and conveyance of various administrative sites within the Allegheny National Forest in Pennsylvania. This Act also addresses the administration of land acquired by the United States and its relation to other conveyance authorities. The Secretary of Agriculture has the authority to convey National Forest System lands and administrative sites in the Allegheny National Forest, Pennsylvania, including Tracts 121, 896, and 1047. The Secretary of Agriculture has the authority to convey National Forest System lands and administrative sites in the Allegheny National Forest, Pennsylvania, including Tracts 121, 896, and 1047. Tract 1047 consists of 4.90 acres and includes the original Marienville Ranger District Headquarters. Tract 844 includes the Marienville ranger residence, with exceptions noted on specific maps. The maps serve as the primary descriptions of the lands, with precedence over metes and bounds descriptions in case of conflicts. The maps are the definitive descriptions of the lands in the Allegheny National Forest, Pennsylvania. In case of conflicts, the maps take precedence over metes and bounds descriptions. The Secretary of Agriculture may accept other land or cash equalization as consideration for conveyance of land. The Secretary may accept other land or a cash equalization payment exceeding 25% of the land value for land exchanges. Conveyances are subject to National Forest System laws. Preference may be given to public entities for land use, and the Secretary can solicit offers. The Secretary may give preference to public entities for land use under this section and can solicit offers with prescribed terms and conditions. Offers may be rejected if deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. Upon conveyance of land, any public order withdrawing the land from appropriation is revoked. Additional terms and conditions may be required by the Secretary for conveyance. The Secretary may impose additional terms and conditions on land conveyances to protect U.S. interests, revoking any public order withdrawing the land from appropriation. The conveyance of Sheffield Ranger District headquarters in Warren County, Pennsylvania is addressed in Section 3. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey US Tract 770, Sheffield Ranger District Headquarters, consisting of 5.50 acres, to the Warren County Development Association for a lump sum payment of $100,000. The map titled "Allegheny Unit, Elk Tanning Company Tract 770, 1934" serves as the primary description of the lands. The map description takes precedence over metes and bounds description in case of conflict. The map must be available for public inspection until the lands are disposed of. Any public order withdrawing land from appropriation laws is revoked upon land conveyance by the Secretary. Conveyance of Ridgeway Ranger District Headquarters in Elk County, Pennsylvania. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey US Tract 904 and US Tract 905 to Ridgeway Township, Pennsylvania, for fair market value as determined by an appraisal. The maps serve as the primary description of the lands being conveyed. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey US Tract 904 and US Tract 905 to Ridgeway Township, Pennsylvania, for fair market value determined by an appraisal. The maps are the primary description of the lands, and on conveyance, any public order withdrawing the land from appropriation under public land laws is revoked. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey Marienville Ranger Residence in Forest County, Pennsylvania. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey, without consideration, to the Marienville Volunteer Fire Department of Forest County, Pennsylvania, all right, title, and interest of the United States in a portion of US Tract 844, Marienville ranger residence. The map titled "Allegheny Unit, Peter B. DeSmet Tract 844, 1936" identifies the portion as Lot 2 on the Survey Plat prepared by D. M. Heller on December 12, 1999. The map is the primary description of the lands, and in case of conflict with metes and bounds description, the map prevails unless it cannot be located. The map is available for public inspection in the Office of the Chief of the Forest Service until the lands are disposed. The map is the definitive description of the lands and will be available for public inspection until disposal. Upon land conveyance, any public order withdrawing the land from appropriation is revoked. SEC. 6. DISPOSITION OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Agriculture shall deposit proceeds from sales or exchanges under section 2 and consideration received under sections 3(b) and 4(b) into the Sisk Act Fund. These funds can be used for acquiring, constructing, or improving administrative facilities and sites in the Allegheny National Forest, as well as acquiring land and interests in land. Land acquisition using these funds is subject to the condition of the market value of the acquired lands. Acquisition of lands in Allegheny National Forest using funds deposited under subsection (a) is subject to the condition that the market value of acquired lands may not exceed 125 percent of the market value of lands disposed of under this Act. SEC. 7. Lands acquired by the Secretary of Agriculture under this Act shall be managed in accordance with the Weeks Act and other relevant laws. The boundaries of Allegheny National Forest will be adjusted based on land disposal and acquisition. SEC. 8. This Act's conveyance authorities are related to other conveyances. SEC. 8. RELATION TO OTHER CONVEYANCES AUTHORITIES. Lands authorized for disposal under this Act shall not be subject to certain provisions of title 40, United States Code.
